facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 112 to 114 of 1968 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution in Original Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 112 to 114 of 1968. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforceent of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Three petitioners challenged promotions to posts of officiating Executive Engineers by first respondent (State of Maharashtra), ignoring petitioners' claims.

anchor.surface_text: The three petitioners by these peti- tions under Art. 32 of the Constitution have challenged the promotion by the first respondent, who, ignoring the claims of the petitioners, have promoted respondents 2 to 5 and other persons similarly situated to the post of officiating Executive Engineers

facts.text: All three petitioners were directly recruited by the Public Service Commission as Deputy Engineers in the Bombay Service of Engineers Class II, now Maharashtra Service of Engineers Class II.

anchor.surface_text: All the three petitioners were directly recruited by the Public Service Commission as Deputy Engineers in the Bombay Service of Engineers Class II, number known as Maharashtra Service of Engineers Class R.

facts.text: First petitioner appointed on 9th June 1959 and confirmed on 9th June 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner was appointed on 9th June 1959, the second petitioner on 11th June 1959 and the third petitioner on 12th June 1959. Though the petitioners were companyfirmed 2 years thereafter, namely, on 9th June 1961, 24th June 1961 and the 18th June 1961 respectively

facts.text: Second petitioner appointed on 11th June 1959 and confirmed on 24th June 1961.

facts.text: Third petitioner appointed on 12th June 1959 and confirmed on 18th June 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner was appointed on 9th June 1959, the second petitioner on 11th June 1959 and the third petitioner on 12th June 1959. Though the petitioners were companyfirmed 2 years thereafter, namely, on 9th June 1961, 24th June 1961 and the 18th June 1961 respectively

facts.text: Government resolution dated 22nd March 1937 framed rules for Bombay and Maharashtra Service of Engineers Class I and II.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay and subsequently the Maharashtra service of engineers companysists of Class I and Class II  Deputy Engineers . They were initially governed by rules framed under the resolutions of the Government in the Public Works Department dated the 22nd March 1937.

facts.text: Government resolution dated 21st November 1941 laid down principles for seniority of direct recruits and promoted officers.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Bombay accordingly by a resolution dated 21st November 1941 laid down the following principles to be applicable to direct recruits and promoted officers in the provincial service except the Bombay Service of Engineers Class I

facts.text: Government resolution dated 29th April 1960 set principles for recruitment to Bombay Service of Engineers Class I and II.

anchor.surface_text: The Government after due companysiderations of the recommendation and the earlier rules regulating the companydition of service in the Bombay Service of Engineers passed a resolution dated 29th April 1960 setting down the principles for recruitment to the Bombay Service of Engineers Class I and Class II.

facts.text: Government resolution dated 29th July 1963 amended rules for seniority of direct recruits and promotees.

anchor.surface_text: On July 29, 1963 the Government of Bombay further amended the rules prescribed in Government Resolution of November 21, 1941 for regulating the seniority of direct recruits and promoted officers.

facts.text: Government resolution dated 4th March 1957 formulated principles for select list of Deputy Engineers for promotion to Executive Engineers.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter by another resolution dated 4th March 1957 the principle for the preparation and maintenance of a select list of Deputy Engineers who were companysidered fit for promotion as Executive Engineers was formulated.

issues.text: Whether the promotions to the post of officiating Executive Engineers were contrary to the principles of natural justice and in violation of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: to the post of officiating Executive Engineers companytrary to the principles of natural justice and in violation of Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution. All the three petitioners were directly recruited by the Public Service Commission as Deputy Engineers in the Bombay Service of Engineers Class II, now known as Maharashtra Service of Engineers Class II.

issues.text: Whether the 7 years qualifying service for promotion to officiating Executive Engineers is to be reckoned from the date of confirmation as Deputy Engineers or from the date of continuous officiating service as Deputy Engineers.

anchor.surface_text: 1957 Rules- Government should review in December each year the claims of all officers in the Bombay Service of Engineers, Class II for promotion to the posts of Executive Engineers by setting up a Committee consisting of the three Chief Engineers under the Chairmanship of the Senior Chief Engineer, which should draw up a select list of those considered by them suitable for promotion.

issues.text: Whether the Government could deem the appointment of respondents from erstwhile Hyderabad State as temporary Deputy Engineers from 31st March 1957 for purposes of seniority and promotion under the States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: while respondent No. 5 to the former State of Madhya Pradesh, and were allocated to the State of Bombay under the States reorganisation. Likewise the other respondents who were formerly in the service of different States referred to above, now belong to the Maharashtra Service of Engineers. The petitioners case is that under the rules in force the respondents who were in the substantive rank of overseers were only officiating Deputy Engineers and that as they did not belong to the cadre of Deputy Engineers they were not entitled to promotion inasmuch as they had to put in after confirmation as Deputy Engineers 7 years of actual service before being eligible for promotion,

arguments.court_reasoning: Recognises just claims; no statutory bar to deeming date.

arguments.claim: Rules of 1960 do not require 7 years permanent service after confirmation for promotion to officiating EE; continuous officiating suffices.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, accept the contention of Shri Gupte that a promotee officiating Deputy Engineer Class II is not entitled to be considered for promotion under r. 7 to the post of an officiating Executive Engineer unless he has put in 7 years of service from the date of confirmation.

arguments.claim: 1963 Resolution clarifies seniority from date of continuous officiation, irrespective temporary/permanent.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the subsequent resolution of the Government of 1963 makes it abundantly clear that the seniority of promotees should be considered as from the date of promotion to officiate continuously irrespective of whether the appointments are made in temporary or permanent vacancies.

arguments.claim: Even 1960 rules lack statutory force under Art.309; merely executive instructions.

anchor.surface_text: there is force in the contention of Shri Kumaramangalam, learned advocate for the respondents, that even the 1960 rules have no statutory force and are no better than the executive instructions issued from time to time by means of resolutions.

arguments.claim: Government entitled to deem Hyderabad respondents' appointment as temp DE from 31-3-57 for seniority/promotion under SRA; no bar.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents who were from Hyderabad State were in fact selected by the Hyderabad Public Service Commission as Assistant Engineers and would have been appointed as such but for the States Reorganisation Act which came into force as from 1-11-1956.

arguments.claim: Promotions on seniority-cum-merit; must consider entitled persons, but no right if not selected after consideration.

anchor.surface_text: When promotions are made on the basis of seniority-cum-merit, all that can be required is that persons entitled to promotion should be considered and if having been considered they have been left out, they would have no claim to promotion as a matter of right.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood.

arguments.claim: Petitioners not included in 1964-65 select lists due to lack of 7 years service and merit; no violation Art14/16.

holdings.text: The rules of 1960 do not require a promotee officiating Deputy Engineer Class II to have put in 7 years of service from the date of confirmation to be eligible for promotion to officiating Executive Engineer; continuous officiating service suffices.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, accept the companytention of Shri Gupte that a promotee officiating Deputy Engineer Class II is number entitled to be companysidered for promotion under r. 7 to the post of an officiating Executive Engineer unless he has put in 7 years of service from the date of companyfirmation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of rr.6,7,8 of 1960 rules shows no requirement for permanent service post-confirmation; temporary/officiating service counts; harmonious with 1963 amendment.

holdings.text: The 1963 Government resolution clarifies that seniority of promotees is reckoned from the date of continuous officiation, irrespective of temporary or permanent vacancies.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the subsequent resolution of the Government of 1963 makes it abundantly clear that the seniority of promotees should be considered as from the date of promotion to officiate continuously irrespective of whether the appointments are made in temporary or permanent vacancies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading supports respondents' interpretation, reinforcing 1960 rules.

holdings.text: The government resolutions of 1960 and 1963 lack statutory force under Article 309 and are merely executive instructions.

anchor.surface_text: there is force in the contention of Shri Kumaramangalam, learned advocate for the respondents, that even the 1960 rules have no statutory force and are no better than the executive instructions issued from time to time by means of resolutions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolutions formulate principles as rules but not made under any law or Art.309; no formalities followed; obiter as 1960 interpretation stands alone.

holdings.text: The Government was entitled to deem the appointment of respondents from Hyderabad (selected pre-reorganisation) as temporary Deputy Engineers from 31st March 1957 for seniority and promotion purposes under the States Reorganisation Act; no statutory bar exists.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents who were from Hyderabad State were in fact selected by the Hyderabad Public Service Commission as Assistant Engineers and would have been appointed as such but for the States Reorganisation Act which came into force as from 1-11-1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recognises just claims of pre-selected candidates disrupted by reorganisation; SRA permits equation of service and fixation of seniority; purposive to avoid injustice.

holdings.text: Promotions on the basis of seniority-cum-merit require only consideration of entitled persons; if considered but found unfit, no claim to promotion as right, following precedent.

anchor.surface_text: When promotions are made on the basis of seniority-cum-merit, all that can be required is that persons entitled to promotion should be considered and if having been considered they have been left out, they would have no claim to promotion as a matter of right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood; merit allows passing over seniors if unfit.

holdings.text: Petitioners not included in 1964-65 select lists due to lack of requisite 7 years service and merit (classes of recommendation); cannot claim violation of Arts. 14 or 16 or mandamus.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit evidence shows consideration per rules; lack of eligibility/merit; no arbitrariness.

precedents.citation: State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood 1

anchor.surface_text: In State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood 1 this Court had so held. Bachawat, J. speaking for the Court observed at p. 366, Where the promotion is based on seniority-cum-merit the officer cannot claim promotion as a matter of right by virtue of his seniority alone. If he is found unfit to discharge the duties of the higher post,

precedents.case_name: State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood
precedents.cited_proposition: Where the promotion is based on seniority-cum-merit the officer cannot claim promotion as a matter of right by virtue of his seniority alone. If he is found unfit to discharge the duties of the higher post, he may be passed over and an officer junior to him may be promoted.
precedents.cited_holding: Where the promotion is based on seniority-cum-merit the officer cannot claim promotion as a matter of right by virtue of his seniority alone. If he is found unfit to discharge the duties of the higher post, he may be passed over and an officer junior to him may be promoted.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners however denied in their rejoinder that the lists were prepared keeping in view the criteria laid down by the rules, but, in our view, it is significant that they did number possess the required length of service in class II for them to be entitled to promotion when the respondents were included in the list and promoted as such they cannot challenge the appointments made as being in violation of Art. 14 or Art. 16.

outcome.relief_summary: Petitioners' challenge to promotions of respondents as officiating Executive Engineers rejected; no violation of Arts. 14 or 16; petitioners lacked requisite service and were not on select list

anchor.surface_text: When promotions are made on the basis of seniority-cum-merit, all that can be required is that persons entitled to promotion should be considered and if having been considered they have been left out, they would have no claim to promotion as a matter of right.

The petitioners however denied in their rejoinder that the lists were prepared keeping in view the criteria laid down by the rules, but, in our view, it is significant that they did number possess the required length of service in class II for them to be entitled to promotion when the respondents were included in the list and promoted as such they cannot challenge the appointments made as being in violation of Art. 14 or Art. 16.
